Comment: White opens with the King pawn
Black plays the French defense.

White pushes the d-pawn one square instead of the more normal two squares to d4.
This move has the disadvantage of blocking the light-square bishop.
In my opinion, nothing is gained by not playing the more normal d4 move.
Black pushes the d-pawn to the centre. Black threatens ...dxe4
White develops the knight
Black develops the kingside knight

White plays c3, which allows the Queen to develop along the diagonal.
However, I think e5 would have been a stronger move.
Black exchanges a pawn.

Instead of recapturing, Which pushes his d-pawn, creating a powerful pawn chain.
However, this move is a mistake. The pawn on e4 is fairly weak, but will take time to re-capture. I think it simply best to for White to have played dxe4
This is White's problem; Black has time to strike out at the powerful chain of pawns with a flank pawn.
White develops the kings knight.
Black develops the Queen's knight
White prepares to fianchetto the Bishop
Black exchanges the flank c-pawn for a central pawn.

White recaptures, and a isolated pawn has appeared.
Black has the advantage, due to the extra pawn.
Black develops the bishop, and pins the knight. Also, the simple ...Nxd4 looks promising for Black.
Black attacks the bishop with a pawn. If Black exchanges bishop for knight, White will gain the bishop pair. In this position the bishop pair would be powerful.
Black avoids the exchange.
White fianchettos the bishop and has a threat to capture the e4 pawn.
Black continues to develop.
